poem:
**Devon Coast Blues**

The sky, once leaden,
glistens above Russell's shore.
Weeks whispered away,
vacant sounds in empty rooms,
hope rekindling in August light—
sun's belated benediction
washes on the Devon coast,
where dreams rust in the salt air,
yet bloom anew
with every warming ray.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Britain’s summer weather has improved, but many holiday operators are still gloomy ‘It has been awful,” said Russell Beale, who has been running a holiday cottage sleeping four on the Devon coast for 14 years. “Typically, we’re let for 26-34 weeks a year and full from Easter until the end of September. This year we’ve had less than 10 weeks of bookings.” As the summer weather improved in August, he said, things had picked up". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.

This year we’ve had less than 10 weeks of bookings.” As the summer weather improved in August, he said, things had picked up
